instruction: Identify some of the main components of a computer network such as hosts, routers, switches, hubs, links, and interfaces. Explain how they communicate and coordinate with each other using protocols and standards such as TCP/IP, HTTP, FTP, DNS, DHCP, and ARP. Describe how data is transmitted and received over a network using concepts such as packets, frames, headers, addresses, ports, sockets, and checksums.
output:
A computer network consists of several components that work together to allow computers to communicate and share resources. Some of the main components of a computer network are:
1. Hosts: These are the computers or devices that are connected to the network. They can be desktop computers, laptops, tablets, smartphones, or any other type of device that can connect to the internet.
2. Routers: These are devices that route traffic between different networks. They make sure that data is transmitted from one network to another in the most efficient way possible.
3. Switches: These are devices that connect multiple hosts to a network. They act as a central hub for the network, allowing data to be transmitted quickly and efficiently.
4. Hubs: These are devices that are used to connect multiple cables together. They act as a repeater, amplifying the signal and allowing it to travel further.
5. Links: These are the physical cables that connect the various components of the network. They can be Ethernet cables, fiber-optic cables, or wireless connections.
6. Interfaces: These are the ports or connections on the various devices that allow them to connect to the network. They can be USB, RJ-45, or other types of connectors.
To communicate and coordinate with each other, the components of a computer network use protocols and standards such as TCP/IP, HTTP, FTP, DNS, DHCP, and ARP. These protocols and standards define how data is transmitted and received over the network, as well as how the various components interact with each other.
TCP/IP (Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol) is the most widely used protocol in computer networks. It is responsible for data transmission and reception over the network, and it breaks down data into smaller pieces called packets. Each packet contains a header that includes

instruction:
I discovered this popular ~9-year-old SO question and decided to double-check its outcomes.

So, I have AMD Ryzen 9 5950X, clang++ 10 and Linux, I copy-pasted code from the question and here is what I got:

Sorted - 0.549702s:

~/d/so_sorting_faster$ cat main.cpp | grep "std::sort" && clang++ -O3 main.cpp && ./a.out
    std::sort(data, data + arraySize);
0.549702
sum = 314931600000
Unsorted - 0.546554s:

~/d/so_sorting_faster $ cat main.cpp | grep "std::sort" && clang++ -O3 main.cpp && ./a.out
    // std::sort(data, data + arraySize);
0.546554
sum = 314931600000
I am pretty sure that the fact that unsorted version turned out to be faster by 3ms is just noise, but it seems it is not slower anymore.

So, what has changed in the architecture of CPU (so that it is not an order of magnitude slower anymore)?
How has artificial intelligence impacted the job market and what can we expect in the future? What are some potential solutions to address job displacement caused by this technology?
output:
Artificial intelligence (AI) has been creating a lot of buzz in recent years. With the advancement of technology and the increasing availability of data, AI has become an integral part of many industries, including healthcare, finance, and entertainment. However, as AI continues to evolve, it is also having a major impact on the job market. In this article, we will explore how AI has affected the job market and what the future might hold.
Impact on the Job Market
One of the most significant ways that AI has affected the job market is through automation. AI-powered machines can now perform tasks that were previously only possible for humans. This has led to the displacement of jobs in industries such as manufacturing, customer service, and even office work. For example, AI-powered robots can now assemble cars, while chatbots can handle basic customer inquiries. As a result, many jobs that used to require human labor are now being replaced by machines.
However, AI has not only caused job displacement. It has also created new job opportunities in areas such as data analysis, machine learning, and AI development. These jobs require specialized skills that are in high demand, especially in industries such as healthcare and finance.
The Future of AI and the Job Market
As AI continues to evolve, it is likely that more jobs will be displaced. However, there are also potential solutions that could be implemented to address job displacement caused by this technology. One solution could be retraining programs that help workers acquire new skills and transition into new careers. Additionally, governments and businesses could invest in education and training initiatives to ensure that workers are equipped with the necessary skills to succeed in the changing job market.
Another solution could be implementing policies that protect workers from job displacement.

instruction:
Rewrite this text in 500 words: "Thereâ€™s much that divides us in Northern Ireland though one thing is guaranteed to bring us together: local phrases. Call it slang, call it colloquialisms, we all know only too well how important words are to where weâ€™re from . . . and when it comes to the phrases that make us â€˜us,â€™ weâ€™ve got a lot to say.
While you donâ€™t need advance knowledge of the words to fit in, well, it helps. How else will you know where â€˜founderedâ€™ sits on the scale of warm to freezing? Or deciding whether that new car purchase is more â€˜clinkerâ€™ than â€˜beezerâ€™? Or appreciating that â€˜grandâ€™ can mean exactly that or anything but?
If the best way to get to know a nation is to understand their language, then surely tourists must be at times confused about what comes out of our mouths. Throughout the island of Ireland, we have utterly brilliant ways to verbally express ourselves.
â€œI think itâ€™s really important,â€ says Dr Frank Ferguson, research director for English Language and Literature at Ulster University, about the vitality of slang as part of language.
â€œI think sometimes weâ€™re not sure even the meaning of slang and the meaning of the vernacular and the colloquial. Especially for Northern Ireland, where language is often so divisive, we forget how a rich and varied it is. And sometimes we find other places in the world that really value the mix of their language.
â€œOften the things that we associate with slang are actually part of the sort of the languages that make up what we think of as English because we have this wonderful mixture of English, Scots language, and Irish, all bubbling up together and then you have the additions on that, of slang,â€ he continues.
â€œSlang as a sort of term thatâ€™s used by certain groups to denote certain things through phrases.
â€œWe have an incredible mix and you think how small in many ways Northern Ireland is, that there are marked differences in the language that Belfast uses and the language thatâ€™s used up in Derry. There are gradation and the usage of words and phrases that we often take for granted but theyâ€™re really quite amazing things.â€
â€œItâ€™s a potentially massive term,â€ says Gail McConnell, a writer from Belfast on slang which she says transcends distinctions of high and low culture.
â€œOne of the reasons why so many of us love [TV show] Derry Girls so much is because it was a language, phrasing and words and speech, that was so familiar, and took such a delight and pleasure in not just Northern Irish slang but Derry-specific slang, which was a joyous thing to see on a Channel 4 programme.
â€œBut then youâ€™ve got someone like Pulitzer Prize-winning Paul Muldoon, the current Ireland Chair of Poetry, whose poems are peppered with slang terms, through all the decades of his writing; heâ€™s been doing that since the 1970s and 1980s to now.
â€œItâ€™s a really interesting legacy of this place and the words that make us unique.â€
Language has the power to unite: it brings familiarity, a sense of community and a feeling that weâ€™re all in this together. It is our primary tool to communicate and finding those lines of unity is vital to create bonds and friendships.
â€œItâ€™s one of those things that if we go on holiday and youâ€™re walking down the street, whether it be Spain or wherever, and you hear something from home. It can be something like â€˜yer maâ€™, or â€˜yer manâ€™ and that will convey a whole host of knowledge and sense of place that somethings donâ€™t and canâ€™t,â€ says Dr Ferguson.
â€œThereâ€™s something very unmistakeably ours about words and phrases that we use and thereâ€™s nothing more honest at times and nothing more radical.
â€œSometimes we might get anxious that weâ€™re using cliches, but weâ€™re actually using things that are very unguarded in our speech.â€
Think too of Line of Dutyâ€™s Ted Hastings, who may be not living in Northern Ireland but ensures his team appreciate he didnâ€™t come up the Lagan in a bubble.
In popular culture, like Gail, Dr Ferguson also references Lisa McGeeâ€™s Derry Girls that unashamedly used phrases and terminology from this place.
â€œThat really said something of the exceptionalism of who we are and what we say.
â€œSometimes weâ€™ve been too quick almost to laugh at ourselves for those words, because I think a lot of it is the way society tries to engineer us with an idea of what is proper language, whereas what we say communicates extremely effectively and works better than sometimes the phraseology of standard English.â€
But our local phrases are not immune from what goes on here.
â€œI think itâ€™s unfortunate that itâ€™s been politicised by a face-off between the Irish language and Ulster Scots,â€ says Gail.
â€œItâ€™s so frustrating but I think thereâ€™s definitely more that we have in common. I think people are often not that sure of the history of slang terms, what the root of it is and where it started.
â€œAnd itâ€™s such a source of comedy; I think some of the best of Irish writing, such as James Joyce, used slang. Itâ€™s one dimension of what slang can do.â€
Dr Ferguson agrees, citing the number of creative writers that Northern Ireland produces who understand the power and ability of language in putting across a moment, or series of moments.
â€œIn many ways, we have a number of registers coming through to us all the time.
â€œWe have that historic mix of English, Scots and Irish, which means then that we can often have two or three words for the same thing.
â€œWe are like the cliche of the Eskimos having so many words for snow; there are, it seems, lots and lots of words out there for â€˜potatoesâ€™ that we have.
â€œCertain areas will have a certain word for certain things and thatâ€™s a real strength. I think thereâ€™s a variety there and thereâ€™s a wonderful history to where those words came from. And even at times, I donâ€™t think weâ€™ve even grasped yet the opportunities that that has for who we are and what we can do and where we can go with that.â€
Again, Ulster Scots is mentioned: a language so many of us use without even knowing. Anyone ever had a â€˜boakâ€™ after a foodstuff not agreeing with them or done â€˜the messagesâ€™? My favourite slang word â€˜hokeâ€™ has an Ulster Scots origin. Itâ€™s fair to say that a discussion on Northern Irish slang cannot be done without looking at Ulster Scots and its continued impact.
â€œOften thereâ€™s not a lot of prestige placed on something like Ulster Scots because there is a perception that itâ€™s bad language, or it doesnâ€™t have a sense of value behind it,â€ says Dr Ferguson.
â€œBut on one hand, you can trace Ulster Scots back into the courtly language of Scotland and you can also get the sense of the authentic place.
â€œThere are bad Ulster Scots writers, just as there are bad Irish writers or bad English writers, or bad French or bad Spanish writers. But when itâ€™s authentic and done well, it transports you to a real sense of realisation that this is really important and fantastic literature and youâ€™re in the room.
â€œWhenever anybody questions me about the validity of Ulster Scots, I say go to Seamus Heaney and he talks about reading [poet] Rabbie Burnsâ€™ To a Mouse and â€˜wee, sleekit, cowrin, timâ€™rous beastieâ€™ appears in the first line.
â€œThis really electrifies him because the word â€˜weeâ€™ appears. Itâ€™s the word that he hears at home in his kitchen language as he calls it and itâ€™s also the word that miraculously appears in the world of art and literature and anthologies.
â€œI think this is when we realised that the very simple words we think weâ€™ve grown up with, weâ€™re maybe a little anxious to use them. When you see the possibilities for those words, thereâ€™s something that really brings us home to just how marvellous our language actually is. And actually how it connects us with lots of people in the country at times when there are things that donâ€™t connect us.â€
Slang has a special place in painting a vivid image of what it is weâ€™re trying to say. It also gives us an insight into a specific culture and attitude. In Northern Irelandâ€™s case, that we have multiple uses for the word â€˜wee.â€™
â€œWe all know how good a wee cup of tea is, a wee rest or a wee drink or a wee day off. These all have their meanings. It can be cold or be freezing but when itâ€™s Baltic, we know exactly what that means and we know weâ€™re foundered,â€ says Dr Ferguson.
â€œOne of our great words, and I think thereâ€™s a difference between the town and city where itâ€™s â€˜scunneredâ€™ or â€˜scunderedâ€™. You can be annoyed and you can be frustrated, but nothing hits home [than] the sense of â€˜I am totally scunneredâ€™ or â€˜I am totally scunderedâ€™ about something. These are things that we should protect.â€
Language too is continuously developing. There are times too when a slang word enters the Oxford English Dictionary (OED) and becomes almost standardised, says Gail.
â€œYesterdayâ€™s slang term is today or the futureâ€™s commonly understood term for something,â€ she explains.
â€œI guess thatâ€™s how language changes and evolves, through its users. Youâ€™re getting a peopleâ€™s history of language use when you think about slang terms. All language passes through users.
â€œEvery year Iâ€™m always interested to see what makes it into the OED â€” it tells you a lot about the way we speak now and how the dictionary has to keep up with the language that people are using.
â€œIn 2022, â€˜a charaâ€™ entered the OED. So did â€˜flutheredâ€™, first used by James Joyce in 1927, â€˜gaslighterâ€™ and â€˜vaxxedâ€™. Itâ€™s great to see Irish English there and words that reflect what weâ€™re living through.â€
Similarly, Dr Ferguson says the â€˜beautyâ€™ of slang is that itâ€™s often at the cutting edge of where words enter into common parlance.
â€œIt often comes from young people so that there is a sense that if somebody like me is using the word, it has long lost its kind of cachet,â€ he laughs.
â€œBut thereâ€™s a thereâ€™s a real sense that this is how words get born and taken into language. Theyâ€™re used in some circles and in some groups.
â€œWe all talk about going to uni now and in a sense, this is Australian dialect that weâ€™ve picked up when Neighbours came along in the 1980s. Suddenly, â€˜uniâ€™ seems one of the obvious words to use because itâ€™s been floating through media, but itâ€™s loaded into everyday speech.
â€œLanguage is always a kind of magpie; it always throws up things for us to use that weâ€™re not expected to use. Even terms that maybe in the past would have had specific meanings for specific groups, suddenly, this becomes widespread.â€
The phrases we barely think about, so bound are they to our identity, are not just ours, however, theyâ€™re widely available for visitors to enjoy â€” on a sock or enamel mug, among other things.
Linzi Rooney is the owner of Born and Bred, a shop celebrating homeware and apparel with a decidedly local twist.
â€œI think itâ€™s actually gotten more popular,â€ she says of the slang-adorned items.
â€œThereâ€™s more of a pride and a confidence that has built up from locals because of who we are and where we come from.
â€œI think that confidence has grown given the number of tourists who are coming into the city. They talk about how friendly we are, they talk about our hospitality and are genuinely interested in the history of the north of Ireland. I think then that our confidence has grown which makes us take a bit more pride in our kind of phrases.â€
She launched the business in 2014 and her ethos remains changing the often negative attitudes about Northern Ireland, creating a culture where weâ€™re proud of the places we call home.
From â€˜up to high dohâ€™ coasters to â€˜a wee bagâ€™ tote, Born and Bred is proudly Northern Irish and equally proud of our famous sayings.
â€œI knew locals would love it and if you see the amount of actual tourists we have coming into the store in Belfast â€” 27% of our tourism comes from Scotland and England,â€ explains Linzi.
â€œWith the Americans coming over and they ask, â€˜Whatâ€™s â€œawk hiya love?â€â€™ â€“ which we have on our socks and mugs â€“ once you explain it to them, they then love it and they buy it. So theyâ€™re running around America with a pair of â€˜awk hiya loveâ€™ socks on with people asking, â€˜Whatâ€™s awk?â€™
â€œIt creates engagement in the shop and itâ€™s probably why the shop is doing so well as itâ€™s creating that kind of dialogue with tourists in the shop as opposed to going in, buying something and leaving.
â€œIt opens conversations which is brilliant.â€
Top of the festive socks for 2022 was a pair with â€˜alright big ladâ€™ and customers still love â€˜Ulster says yeooo!â€™ and â€˜ats us naiâ€™.
â€œHaving tourists back last year and also cruise ships was definitely a real confidence boost for the shop,â€ continues Linzi.
â€œFor the last two years before that, in and around lockdowns, you were relying on local trade which was amazing.
Thereâ€™s no greater feeling than somebody coming from Spain, China, Italy, America, Canada, and really loving something with a local sign on it.â€
How a brand markets items with such a local angle is important, she says.
â€œI was always very conscious that itâ€™s how you incorporate this kind of slang with your brand, and create a brand that people want to invest in and itâ€™s a lifestyle brand. When you do that and add a bit of Northern Irish tongue in cheek, itâ€™s quite popular.
â€œIt may not want to be a mug youâ€™d have in your house but when you add the pink and enamel and people will take pictures of it up the Mournes or are wearing their â€˜alrightâ€™ sock in a style thatâ€™s trendy and you can see yourself wearing it. If youâ€™re able to tie those two together then youâ€™ve got a good product. Itâ€™s not just your fridge magnet with a leprechaun on it.â€
Many households live with multiple words of various things, giving a flavour of the melting point of cultures and nationalities for whom Northern Ireland is home.
â€œIâ€™m married to an American so occasionally with our young son, Beth and I are in disagreement about the things we say,â€ says Gail. â€œSimple things like Iâ€™ll say â€˜plasterâ€™ and sheâ€™ll say â€˜Band-aid,â€™ Iâ€™ll say â€˜chipsâ€™ and sheâ€™ll say â€˜friesâ€™. He knows that heâ€™s betwixt and between terms.
â€œEven things like â€˜weeâ€™ and â€˜whatâ€™s the craic?â€™ There are phrases I would say that, in the mouth of someone whoâ€™s not from here, they sound ridiculous. You can hear people, and English speakers in particular, trying to accommodate themselves, â€˜Well, hello, whatâ€™s the craic?â€™ Or even words like â€˜scunderedâ€™ or â€˜jammy,â€™ or â€˜dead on,â€™ all these things that I say quite often.â€"
